QuizInc presents the second edition of Global Glimpses where we revisit the history of the Forgotten City in Beijing, China. Built during the Ming Dynasty in the early 15th century, the Forbidden City served as the imperial palace and political center of China for over five centuries, housing emperors and their households. Covering over 180 acres and containing over 980 buildings, the Forbidden City is renowned for its traditional Chinese architecture, grand halls, pavilions, and courtyards adorned with intricate decorations and imperial treasures. As a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1987, the Forbidden City symbolizes China's imperial history and cultural heritage. It attracts millions of visitors annually, offering insights into the country's dynastic past and influencing global perceptions of Chinese art, architecture, and governance.

Article published EXPLORING THE INTRICATE ARCHITECTURAL FABRIC OF A HISTORIC ARAB MEDINA: A STUDY OF NABLUS OLD TOWN Core to the Yalla Project is to cultivate a collaborative network among researchers to generate trustworthy knowledge concerning our built environment. We closed the last year with one of the initial achievements towards this objective, exemplified by the publication of an article. This paper was conceived, discussed, and developed through collaborative efforts with Dr. Ameen Abu Bakr, a distinguished history professor at An-Najah National University. Our collaboration was born through our social caf√© Antique, in the historic precinct of Nablus, which we used to sit in for a break from time to time. Our amicable coffee table chats took off towards a substantial academic collaboration. This contribution unveils noteworthy and unexpected methodologies employed by our ancestors in crafting a refined yet sustainable built environment. The article particularly elucidates the intriguing practices of micro place-making as observed among the populace of Nablus in Palestine during the Ottoman era. This publication is the outcome of an extensive multi-year investigation into the processes of place-making within the Islamic city, based on the interdisciplinary analysis of Ottoman archives in the Nablus area. The study was conducted through a meticulous examination of archival materials spanning 400 years. The study reveals a high degree of freedom to act, reciprocity, and distinctive perspectives regarding architectural compositions.
